sectionTitle: C.5: Jain Ethics and the Environment

tabData.tagHTML: Jainism teaches that the five basic elements of our environment—Earth, Water, Fire, Air, and Vegetation—are themselves living beings, each possessing the sense of touch. The ancient Jain aphorism, 'Parasparopagraho Jivänäm' (All life is bound together by mutual support and interdependence), forms the basis of the modern science of ecology.

Because all life is interconnected, harming any part of the environment is harming ourselves. Greed and possessiveness are seen as the primary causes of violence and environmental imbalance. The three cardinal principles of Jainism provide a framework for ethical and eco-friendly living.

tabData.title: The Pillars of Jain Environmental Ethics
tabData.description: Ahimsä, Anekäntaväd, and Aparigraha are the core principles guiding a Jain's interaction with the world.

items.content: This is the supreme duty. It means respecting all life and avoiding harm not just in action, but also in speech and thought. It is an active concern for the welfare of all beings, from humans and animals down to the elements of air and water.

This is respect for the views of others. It is the understanding that truth is complex and has many sides, and no single viewpoint holds the absolute truth. This principle stops the violence of rigid, dogmatic thought and promotes understanding and harmony.

This is respect for the environment by limiting one's needs and desires. Accumulating possessions leads to greed, jealousy, and violence. Using resources beyond one's need is a form of theft, and creating waste and pollution are acts of violence against the planet.

tabData.title: Practical Application of Jain Ethics
tabData.description: How Jain principles apply to modern issues like the dairy industry and consumerism.

items.content: While Jains are vegetarian, most consume dairy. However, the modern dairy industry inflicts terrible cruelty on cows, treating them as milk-producing machines. They are kept constantly pregnant, injected with hormones, separated from their calves, and sent to slaughterhouses when their milk production drops. This violence is why many Jains are re-evaluating the use of dairy products, especially in religious rituals.

items.header: The Three R's: A Jain Practice
items.content:
The principles of Aparigraha and Ahimsä naturally lead to an eco-friendly lifestyle.
  • Reduce: Minimize needs and consumption. Buy products with less packaging.
  • Reuse: Use items multiple times. Give away unwanted clothes and items instead of throwing them away.
  • Recycle: Collect and re-process materials like paper, glass, and plastic. Support the cycle by purchasing products made from recycled materials.
